Docs.summary: This interface provides application information. See and for concretes implementations and usage.
Adds a content type to the application.
Docs.returns: Always returns True. Throw a if something went wrong.

remarks.para: Adds a content type to the application information to indicate the application is capable of opening files with the given content type.
This method always returns True, or throw a if something went wrong.

Docs.summary: If a supported content type can be removed from an application.
Docs.value: True if it is possible to remove supported content types from the application, False if not.

Docs.summary: An human-readable description of an installed application.
Docs.value: A string containing a description of the application, or null if none.

Docs.summary: The executable's name for the installed application.
Docs.value: A string containing the AppInfo's application binary's name.
A string containing the application's ID.
Docs.remarks: An id si s a string that identifies the application. The exact format of the id is platform depenedent. For instance, on Unix, this is the desktop file id from the xdg menu specification.

MemberSignature.Value: public bool Launch (GLib.List files, GLib.AppLaunchContext launch_context);

Docs.param: A of objects, or null to launch the application without arguments.
Docs.returns: Always returns True. Throws a if something went wrong.

remarks.para: Launches the application. Passes files to the launched application as arguments, using the optional launch_context to get information about the details of the launcher (like what screen it is on). Throws a on error.
To lauch the application without arguments pass a null files list.
Note that even if the launch is successful the application launched can fail to start if it runs into problems during startup. There is no way to detect this.

Some URIs can be changed when passed through a GFile (for instance unsupported uris with strange formats like mailto:), so if you have a textual uri you want to pass in as argument, consider using instead.

MemberSignature.Value: public bool LaunchUris (GLib.List uris, GLib.AppLaunchContext launch_context);

Docs.param: A of containing URIs to launch, or null.
Docs.returns: Always returns True. Throws a if something went wrong.

remarks.para: Launches the application. Passes uris to the launched application as arguments, using the optional launch_context to get information about the details of the launcher (like what screen it is on). On error, throws a
To lauch the application without arguments pass a NULL uris list.
Note that even if the launch is successful the application launched can fail to start if it runs into problems during startup. There is no way to detect this.

Docs.summary: The name of the installed application.
Docs.value: A containing the name of the application.

Docs.param: A containing a content type. On Unix, content types are mimetypes, so "image/jpeg" is a valid content type.
Docs.summary: Removes a supported type from an application, if possible.
Docs.returns: Always returns True. Throws a if something went wrong.
Docs.remarks: This method always returns True, but throws on any error. Checking first will avoid some exceptions, but that doesn't mean it won't throw at all.

Docs.param: A containing the file extension (without the dot).
Docs.summary: Sets the application as the default handler for the given file extension.
Docs.returns: Always returns True. Throws a if something went wrong.
Docs.remarks: This method always returns True, or throw a if something went wrong.

Docs.summary: Sets the application as the default handler for a given type.
Docs.returns: Always returns True. Throws a if something went wrong.
Docs.remarks: This method always returns True, or throw a if something went wrong.

Docs.summary: If the application info should be shown in menus that list available applications.
Docs.value: True if the application should be shown, False otherwise.

Docs.summary: If the application accepts files as arguments.
Docs.value: True if the application supports files.

Docs.summary: If the application supports reading files and directories from URIs.
Docs.value: True if the application supports URIs.
